columns.text: In this exercise, we will determine the monthly payment for the new sports car from Muscle Motors we want to purchase at $57,500 if the contract is 60 months in the form of an annuity due with an APR of 5.9%.

We will consider the following details from the problem in solving the monthly payment.

| Particulars        |         |
|--------------------|---------|
| APR | 5.9% |
| Cost of the sports car      | $57,500    |
| Period             | 60       |

First, determine the monthly rate of the APR.

The APR refers to the *annual percentage rate* or the stated rate a lender can quote in its loan. APR is calculated by multiplying the monthly rate by the number of months in the year. Hence to determine the monthly rate, we will divide the APR by the number of months in a year. We will consider the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Monthly rate} &=\dfrac{\text{APR}}{\text{12}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Next, calculate the present value of the annuity due.

An annuity due is an annuity where the payment is made or due at the beginning of the period. To determine the present value of the annuity due without the periodic payment, we will divide the present value of an ordinary annuity by the rate factor. Hence, we will consider the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{PV of Annuity Due} &= \dfrac{\text{PV of Ordinary Annuity}} {\left(1+r\right)}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PV$, which means the present value\
$r$, which refers to the rate
Considering the 0.49% monthly rate from the previous calculation, assume the $57,500 cost of the sports car as the present value of the ordinary annuity to calculate the present value annuity due.
Finally, assuming the present value of the annuity due and the monthly rate, we will now calculate the monthly payment for the sports car.

In calculating the sports car, we will use the spreadsheet function PMT. The PMT is a financial function that calculates the periodic payment based on the present value, interest rate, and the loans period. Hence the formula of the PMT function is as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
PMT&=(\text{rate},nper,pv,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PMT$, which presents the annual cash flows\
$nper$, which refers to the period\
$pv$, which represent the present value\
$fv$, the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end (0) or beginning of the year (1)
We'll set a value of 1 in the PMT spreadsheet calculation since annuity payments are paid at the start of the year, so the basis of the calculation will be at the beginning of the year.

Let's now calculate the monthly payment in a spreadsheet. Note that the present value should be negative for the function to work correctly.


!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/2797f2b8-ccb0-4cfe-8a01-b8798867bb94-1644471604664245.png)

**As a result, the monthly payment for the sports car is $1,103.54, as shown in our calculations.**
To sum up, we used the present value of the annuity due, and the monthly interest rate from the APR provided to calculate the monthly payment of $1,103.54 to acquire the sports car.
